subsc: Agricultural extension and research,Irrigation and drainage

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was
            satisfactory because the project, amongst other
            interventions, succeeded in helping raise the overall
            conveyance system efficiency in the Jordan Valley to 80
            percent. the sustainability of project investments is likely
            because of the innovation made to assign responsibility for
            the bulk of the physical investments to farmers, and the
            human capacity developed. Overall World Bank and Borrower
            performances were rated as satisfactory, although there were
            delays in implementation. Key lessons learned included the
            following: Decentralizing investments downstream of pumping
            stations to private operators, especially farmers, would
            help promote the sustainability of the irrigation system at
            that level. A first step was made to relocate farm turnouts
            from their customary location on access roads to on-farm,
            with individual farmers being held accountable for them and
            the related costs recovered directly from them in cases of
            meter tampering. Apart from promoting sustainability, this
            approach has also reduced the fiscal costs of these
            investments. Although some monitoring of the project's
            effects and some monitoring capacity was built in to the
            agriculture ministry, these efforts slowed and were not
            effectively used by the government to address the impacts of
            sector reforms on the poor. Internal clearance mechanisms
            used by the Government to review small equipment purchases
            resulted in needless delays and transaction costs. he Bank
            for no
